papers.abstract: This article sheds light on the methods and meaning of W. E. B. Du Bois’ 1899 study of the everyday lives of Black residents of Philadelphia’s Seventh Ward. It does so by juxtaposing the way Du Bois conducted his research with our contemporary efforts to recover, recreate, and preserve The Philadelphia Negro using digital and geospatial technologies to document historical and contemporary patterns relating to race and class. Beginning with an exploration of primary source documents that provide new details about how Du Bois went about his original research, we focus on the humanities and social science research methods that he employed. Of note is the color-coded parcel-level map Du Bois created to illustrate Black social class status, which reflected both the influence of the Social Survey Movement and Du Bois’ efforts to present a new understanding of the color line. His findings were groundbreaking, considering that most white scientists of his time assumed Black people to be biologically inferior and socially homogeneous. Instead, he documented the variability and social stratification within Philadelphia’s Black population and the systematic exclusion they faced because of anti-Black racism. Our ongoing project — The WARD: Race and Class in Du Bois’ Seventh Ward, which seeks to recreate Du Bois’ study — includes new technologies and participatory research methods that engage high school and college students. In-depth, intergenerational oral histories conducted with students also add a new dimension to this work and complement our high school curriculum, which incorporates online mapping, documentaries, a board game, a walking tour, and a mural to engage others to create their own primary sources. This research provides a historical context for today’s racial tensions as we seek new ways to address the 21st century color line.

events.Text: This article sheds light on the methods and meaning of W. E. B. Du Bois’ 1899 study of the everyday lives of Black residents of Philadelphia’s Seventh Ward. It does so by juxtaposing the way Du Bois conducted his research with our contemporary efforts to recover, recreate, and preserve The Philadelphia Negro using digital and geospatial technologies to document historical and contemporary patterns relating to race and class.
events.Main Action: conducted his research while juxtaposing it with current efforts

Primary Object: historical data collected during Du Bois' study and digital/geospatial technologies currently employed

Context: The article discusses how Du Bois' 1899 study relates to contemporary efforts to recover and preserve The Philadelphia Negro using digital and geospatial technologies.
It highlights the evolution and integration of methodologies over time.
Method: historical fieldwork and application of digital/geospatial technologies
Results: Through this combination, the authors demonstrate effective documentation of racial and socioeconomic patterns over decades.
Implications: Such integrative approaches may pave the way for enhanced interdisciplinary research in urban history and digital humanities.

events.Text: Beginning with an exploration of primary source documents that provide new details about how Du Bois went about his original research, we focus on the humanities and social science research methods that he employed. Of note is the color-coded parcel-level map Du Bois created to illustrate Black social class status, which reflected both the influence of the Social Survey Movement and Du Bois’ efforts to present a new understanding of the color line.

Primary Object: a color-coded parcel-level map to illustrate Black social class status
Secondary Object: which reflected both the influence of the Social Survey Movement and Du Bois’ efforts to present a new understanding of the color line

Context: Of note is the color-coded parcel-level map Du Bois created to illustrate Black social class status, which reflected both the influence of the Social Survey Movement and Du Bois’ efforts to present a new understanding of the color line.

events.Text: His findings were groundbreaking, considering that most white scientists of his time assumed Black people to be biologically inferior and socially homogeneous. Instead, he documented the variability and social stratification within Philadelphia’s Black population and the systematic exclusion they faced because of anti-Black racism.

Primary Object: variety and social stratification within Philadelphia’s Black population
Secondary Object: systematic exclusion they faced because of anti-Black racism

Context: most white scientists of his time assumed Black people to be biologically inferior and socially homogeneous
Results: He revealed significant issues regarding anti-Black racism due to their exclusion
Implications: These findings imply the necessity of exploring systemic inequalities and developing strategies to address racial discrimination effectively in urban settings.

events.Text: Our ongoing project — The WARD: Race and Class in Du Bois’ Seventh Ward, which seeks to recreate Du Bois’ study — includes new technologies and participatory research methods that engage high school and college students. In-depth, intergenerational oral histories conducted with students also add a new dimension to this work and complement our high school curriculum, which incorporates online mapping, documentaries, a board game, a walking tour, and a mural to engage others to create their own primary sources. This research provides a historical context for today’s racial tensions as we seek new ways to address the 21st century color line.

Primary Object: new technologies and participatory research methods

Context: The project aims to replicate Du Bois’ study using modern methods including online mapping, documentaries, a board game, a walking tour, and a mural.
Purpose: To engage students in meaningful research and promote understanding of race and class issues in Du Bois’ original context while introducing innovative teaching tools.<NONE>
Method: Participatory research methods, collaboration with local communities, and integration of multimedia content.<NONE>
Results: Increased student involvement led to heightened awareness of social justice issues and creation of public art that sparked conversations.<NONE>
Analysis: Students reported enhanced learning experiences through hands-on involvement and creative expression.<NONE>
Challenge: Balancing extensive student participation with maintaining academic rigor was challenging.<NONE>
Ethical: Involving minors requires adherence to ethical guidelines regarding consent and privacy.<NONE>
Implications: Such integrated approaches offer valuable lessons for designing educational programs that foster civic engagement and empathy.<NONE>

papers.abstract: This article examines how Black fans utilize social media platforms to engage fandoms of contemporary Black popular cultural productions. Specifically, how Black digital intimacies are created through examining the interiority expressed in the cultural productions and their fandoms. Utilizing YouTube and Twitter fan comments from The Mis-Adventures of Awkward Black Girl [YouTube, 2011-2012] and Insecure [HBO, 2016-2021], this article proposes affirmative transformative fandom to examine the affective relationships fans have with their fan objects and fellow fans to explore their own intimate lives.

events.Text: This article examines how Black fans utilize social media platforms to engage fandoms of contemporary Black popular cultural productions. Specifically, how Black digital intimacies are created through examining the interiority expressed in the cultural productions and their fandoms.

Utilizing YouTube and Twitter fan comments from The Mis-Adventures of Awkward Black Girl [YouTube, 2011-2012] and Insecure [HBO, 2016-2021], this article proposes affirmative transformative fandom to examine the affective relationships fans have with their fan objects and fellow fans to explore their own intimate lives.

Secondary Object: towards their fan objects and fellow fans

Context: this article proposes ... examine the affective relationships fans have with their fan objects and fellow fans to explore their own intimate lives
